title: Your First hATTR Amyloidosis Appointment
author: Hallie Levine

content: It can be scary to learn that you have hATTR amyloidosis . It’s a very rare inherited disease that happens because of a mutation in a gene called the TTR gene. This leads to a buildup of abnormal proteins called amyloids in organs like your heart, kidneys, nervous system, and digestive tract. As a result, they don’t work properly.
If you’ve been recently diagnosed, or if you or your doctor suspects that you have hATTR, you’ll have a lot of questions at your first appointment. Here’s a look at what to expect.
There are over 120 types of TTR gene variants. You may be more likely to have one based on your background or where you're from.

content_blocks.text: It can be scary to learn that you have hATTR amyloidosis . It’s a very rare inherited disease that happens because of a mutation in a gene called the TTR gene. This leads to a buildup of abnormal proteins called amyloids in organs like your heart, kidneys, nervous system, and digestive tract. As a result, they don’t work properly.
If you’ve been recently diagnosed, or if you or your doctor suspects that you have hATTR, you’ll have a lot of questions at your first appointment. Here’s a look at what to expect.
There are over 120 types of TTR gene variants. You may be more likely to have one based on your background or where you're from.

sections.heading: How Should I Prepare for My hATTR Appointment?
content: Know your family health history . hATTR is autosomal dominant. That means that if one of your parents has the gene mutation, there’s a 50% chance that you’ll inherit it, too. If you have a parent, sibling, or child with the condition, you should get genetic testing , even if you don’t have any symptoms of the disease.

Bring any test results . Your doctor will want to know if you have had any genetic testing to look for the TTR gene variant. These are blood or saliva tests that analyze your TTR gene and look for specific mutations. There are over 120 types, but the three most common ones are:

content_blocks.text: Know your family health history . hATTR is autosomal dominant. That means that if one of your parents has the gene mutation, there’s a 50% chance that you’ll inherit it, too. If you have a parent, sibling, or child with the condition, you should get genetic testing , even if you don’t have any symptoms of the disease.

Bring any test results . Your doctor will want to know if you have had any genetic testing to look for the TTR gene variant. These are blood or saliva tests that analyze your TTR gene and look for specific mutations. There are over 120 types, but the three most common ones are:

sections.heading: ATTR V30M variant.
content: This one is found mainly in people of Portuguese, Spanish, French, Swedish, or Japanese descent.
ATTR V122I variant. This variant is found in up to 4% of all African Americans.
ATTR T60A variant. This type is found in people from the U.K. and Ireland.
Keep in mind that even if you’ve tested positive for a TTR gene variant, that doesn’t mean you’ll get hATTR. Your doctor will want to run more tests first.

ATTR T60A variant. This type is found in people from the U.K. and Ireland.
Keep in mind that even if you’ve tested positive for a TTR gene variant, that doesn’t mean you’ll get hATTR. Your doctor will want to run more tests first.

sections.heading: What Sort of Tests Will My Doctor Order at My hATTR Appointment?
content: If you’ve been formally diagnosed with hATTR, or suspect that you have the condition, your doctor will most likely give you a thorough physical exam. But there are many other tests they may order to both diagnose and monitor your disease. Here are some of the tests they may suggest:

sections.heading: What Sort of Tests Will My Doctor Order at My hATTR Appointment?
content: If you’ve been formally diagnosed with hATTR, or suspect that you have the condition, your doctor will most likely give you a thorough physical exam. But there are many other tests they may order to both diagnose and monitor your disease. Here are some of the tests they may suggest:

content_blocks.text: If you’ve been formally diagnosed with hATTR, or suspect that you have the condition, your doctor will most likely give you a thorough physical exam. But there are many other tests they may order to both diagnose and monitor your disease. Here are some of the tests they may suggest:

sections.heading: Biopsy
content: . This test is done to confirm that you have hATTR. It checks for amyloid deposits in your tissue (usually in your belly) and figures out the identity of the protein that causes them.

content_blocks.text: . This test is done to confirm that you have hATTR. It checks for amyloid deposits in your tissue (usually in your belly) and figures out the identity of the protein that causes them.

sections.heading: Blood and urine tests
content: . These look for proteins that can indicate hATTR.
Scintigraphy . This is a type of bone scan that looks for amyloid deposits in your heart.
Once hATTR is diagnosed, your doctor may recommend the following tests to see how hATTR has affected your organs:
Echocardiogram and/or a cardiac MRI . These tests look for heart damage.
Nerve conduction tests. These check for nerve damage.

content_blocks.text: . These look for proteins that can indicate hATTR.

Once hATTR is diagnosed, your doctor may recommend the following tests to see how hATTR has affected your organs:
Echocardiogram and/or a cardiac MRI . These tests look for heart damage.

sections.heading: What’ll My Doctor Ask Me?
content: Your doctor will want to know how you feel, and whether or not you’re having any symptoms that may be related to your hATTR. It’s important to remember that hATTR may affect several parts of your body. If you’ve noticed any of the below, let your doctor know:
Nerve damage. This can lead to the following symptoms:
Heart damage . hATTR can affect your heart and lead to heart failure. Watch for symptoms like:

sections.heading: Damage to your autonomic nervous system
content: . This is the part of your nervous system that controls involuntary functions like breathing and heart rate. You may have:
Other symptoms to watch for include blurry or spotty vision, headaches, signs of dementia, seizures, or stroke -like episodes.
bullets: GI issues like nausea , vomiting, diarrhea , or constipation

sections.heading: What Treatments for hATTR Will My Doctor Recommend?
content: Years ago, the only treatment for hATTR was a liver transplant. Now, new drugs can help slow down the progression of this disease. Your doctor will suggest treatments based on three things:
hATTR itself is classified into four stages:
Stage 0. No symptoms, but you have a positive TTR gene mutation test.
bullets: Which tissues and organs are affected

bullets: Which tissues and organs are affected

content_blocks.text: hATTR itself is classified into four stages:
Stage 0. No symptoms, but you have a positive TTR gene mutation test.

sections.heading: Stage 1.
content: You can walk normally but notice mild tingling, numbness, and pain from nerve damage in your legs and feet.

content_blocks.text: You can walk normally but notice mild tingling, numbness, and pain from nerve damage in your legs and feet.

sections.heading: Stage II.
content: You need help walking. You may also notice tingling, numbness, and pain from nerve damage in your upper and lower limbs, as well as your trunk.
Stage III. Your symptoms are so bad, you’re in a wheelchair or even bedridden.
Here’s a look at some of the medication options your doctor may suggest.

TTR gene silencers . These drugs slow down the production of TTR proteins. This makes it less likely that amyloid will build up in your body. There are four FDA-approved drugs in this category. They are all approved for stage I or II of hATTR. They include:

TTR stabilizers. They work to prevent TTR proteins from misfolding and forming amyloid deposits. They’ve also been shown to help slow down cardiomyopathy , or an enlarged heart due to damage to the heart muscle. Drugs in this category are:
Amyloid fibril degraders . These drugs break down amyloid deposits. These include:
Monoclonal antibodies. These drugs are in clinical trials. They’ve been shown to target amyloid deposits and break them down.
bullets: Green tea. It contains epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG), which may inhibit amyloid. It’s available over the counter as a capsule.

sections.heading: What Other Specialists Will My Doctor Recommend for hATTR?
content: Since hATTR can impact different parts of your body, your doctor will most likely recommend that you see other specialists to treat certain symptoms. For example, they may suggest:

Your doctor will also talk to you about your prognosis, or how long they expect you to live. The survival rate can be anywhere from 3 to 15 years after your diagnosis. Keep in mind that it depends on which specific gene mutation you have, and which organs it’s affected. New treatments are being researched and developed as well, which may offer new options and outcomes in the future.
bullets: A cardiologist to treat heart palpitations and signs of heart failure
A gut specialist to treat stomach upsets such as diarrhea and/or constipation
A urologist if you have problems peeing
An eye doctor if you have eye issues such as floaters
An orthopedic specialist if you develop carpal tunnel syndrome

meta_description: You’ll have a lot of questions at your first hATTR appointment. What is hATTR? What’s the prognosis? What are the symptoms and treatment? Here’s a guide.
